title: 115_hr620
content: The Act may be cited as the "ADA Education and Reform Act of 2017" and focuses on compliance through education. The Disability Rights Section of the Department of Justice will develop a program to educate State and local governments and property owners on promoting access to public accommodations for persons with disabilities. This program may include training for professionals to provide guidance on ADA compliance. Additionally, materials will be provided in other languages for better accessibility. The Act requires materials on compliance and amendments to be available in languages commonly used by US businesses. SEC. 3. NOTICE AND CURE PERIOD. Paragraph (1) of section 308(a) of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to provide remedies and procedures for discrimination based on disability, as outlined in the Civil Rights Act of 1964. No futile gestures are required if a person with a disability has notice of discrimination. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 provides remedies and procedures for discrimination based on disability. A civil action for failure to remove architectural barriers in public accommodations requires a specific written notice to the owner or operator. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 outlines procedures for addressing discrimination based on disability, including the requirement for a written notice to the owner or operator regarding architectural barriers in public accommodations. If the owner fails to provide a written description of improvements to remove the barrier within 60 days, or fails to make substantial progress in removing the barrier, they may be subject to legal action. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 requires a written notice to address discrimination based on disability regarding architectural barriers in public accommodations. The notice must detail the circumstances of the denial of access, including the property address, request for assistance, and the nature of the barrier. Failure to address the barrier within 60 days may result in legal action. The Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment. Mediation is available for ADA actions related to architectural barriers. SEC. 5. The Judicial Conference of the United States will develop a model program for mediation of ADA actions related to architectural barriers in consultation with property owners and disability rights representatives. The program aims to resolve claims efficiently without costly litigation, including a stay of discovery during mediation and an expedited method for determining relevant facts. The House of Representatives passed the bill on February 15, 2018. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
